items.title: Here are all the tech companies rolling back DEI or still committed to it — so far
items.summary:
- Companies in the U.S. are cutting DEI programs due to legal and political pressures from the Trump administration.
- Attorney General Pam Bondi instructed the Department of Justice to target DEI programs in companies receiving federal funds.
- Trump signed an executive order banning DEI initiatives in the federal government, supported by Elon Musk.
- Major corporations like McDonalds, Harley Davidson, and Goldman Sachs are reducing or eliminating DEI policies.
- Companies such as Apple and JPMorgan are maintaining their commitment to diversity initiatives.
- Google is not renewing diversity hiring targets and will review existing DEI initiatives to comply with new regulations.
- Meta is significantly scaling back its DEI efforts and has eliminated its DEI team.
- Many companies are scrubbing mentions of DEI from official filings and public documents.

items.title: Inception emerges from stealth with a new type of AI model
items.author: Stefano Ermon, Aditya Grover, Volodymyr Kuleshov
items.summary:
- Inception is a Palo Alto-based company founded by Stanford professor Stefano Ermon, focused on a new diffusion-based AI model called DLM.
- Inception's model combines the capabilities of traditional LLMs with faster performance and lower costs.
- The model allows for generating and modifying large blocks of text in parallel, unlike traditional LLMs which are sequential.
- Inception has already secured customers, including Fortune 100 companies, addressing a need for reduced AI latency.
- The company offers an API and various deployment options, claiming its DLMs are up to 10x faster and cost 10x less than traditional LLMs.
- A company spokesperson stated that their models can perform as well as OpenAI’s GPT-4o mini but with greater speed.

items.title: Hacked crypto exchange Bybit offers $140 million bounty to trace stolen funds
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Hackers stole around $1.4 billion in Ethereum from Bybit, the largest crypto heist in history.
- Bybit is offering $140 million in bounties for tracing and freezing the stolen funds.
- CEO Ben Zhou announced the bounty on X, with rewards of 5% for those who trace and 5% for the entity that freezes the funds.
- $4.23 million has already been awarded to bounty hunters.
- The cybersecurity group Lazarus, linked to North Korea, is suspected to be behind the hack.
- Security firms reported that a developer's device at SafeWallet was breached, leading to the hack.

items.title: ElevenLabs is launching its own speech-to-text model
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- ElevenLabs launches its first standalone speech-to-text model called Scribe.
- The model supports over 99 languages, with over 25 offering excellent accuracy (less than 5% word error rate).
- It claims to outperform Google Gemini 2.0 Flash and Whisper Large V3 in benchmark tests.
- Pricing is set at $0.40 per hour of transcribed audio, competitive among rivals.
- Scribe currently works only with pre-recorded audio; a real-time version will be released soon.
- Features include speaker diarization, word-level timestamps, and auto-tagging of sounds.
- The company aims to improve speech detection beyond existing solutions.

items.title: Pixel Watch 3 is getting ‘Loss of Pulse Detection’ in the US in March
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google has received FDA clearance for the Pixel Watch 3’s Loss of Pulse Detection feature, launching in the U.S. by the end of March.
- The feature detects when a user's heart stops beating due to various emergencies and can automatically call for help if the user is unresponsive.
- Loss of Pulse Detection was first launched in the EU in September 2024, now available in 14 countries.
- The feature utilizes AI-driven algorithms, combining pulse check with physiological and motion data.
- Google warns that it may not detect every loss of pulse and is not a substitute for medical care or monitoring.

items.title: Hinge launches a new feature for daters to privately share details with matches
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Hinge launched a new feature called “Match Note” that allows users to privately share information with matches.
- The note is visible to new matches but can be read only once, requiring acknowledgment to begin conversation.
- Designed to support underrepresented groups like LGBTQIA+ and neurodivergent users, allowing them to share sensitive information discreetly.

items.title: Alexa+ can read, summarize and recall lengthy documents
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Amazon introduced Alexa+, a new version of its voice assistant powered by generative AI.
- Users can share documents with Alexa+, allowing it to recall details and answer questions related to those documents.
- Demonstrations showed Alexa+ extracting information from recipes and HOA guidelines, as well as summarizing school emails.

items.title: Amazon Alexa+ can do your grocery shopping, too
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Amazon launches Alexa+, a revamped version of its virtual shopping assistant for grocery shopping.
- The new feature allows users to shop through natural language conversations.
- Works with Amazon Fresh and other grocery partners, including food delivery from Uber Eats.
- Alexa can help build shopping lists and adjust quantities dynamically based on user requests.
- The upgraded Alexa+ will be available in March for $19.99 a month, free for Prime members.

items.title: Alexa+ can do your grocery shopping, too
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Amazon introduces Alexa+, a revamped experience allowing grocery shopping through natural conversations.
- Alexa can assist with shopping using Amazon Fresh or other grocery partners and delivery services like Uber Eats.
- The assistant enables users to build shopping lists via voice commands, adjusting quantities and offering meal suggestions based on preferences.
- The Alexa+ upgrade will be available in March for $19.99 per month, free for Prime members.

items.title: Amazon Alexa+ costs $19.99, free for Prime members
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Amazon’s new Alexa+ launches at $19.99, free for Prime members.
- Early access begins next month in the U.S., with wider rollout in subsequent months.
- Compatible devices include Echo Show 8, 10, 15, and 21; other devices' support is unclear.
- Introduction of Alexa.com for long-form work and a refreshed mobile app.
- Pricing competitive with other AI chatbots like ChatGPT and Google’s Gemini Advanced.
- Initial expectations were for a price between $5 to $10.

items.title: Alexa+ costs $19.99, free for Amazon Prime members
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Amazon's Alexa+ launch price is $19.99, free for Amazon Prime members.
- Early access begins next month in the U.S., with broader rollout over subsequent months.
- Compatible devices include Echo Show 8, 10, 15, and 21; support for other devices unclear.
- Introduction of Alexa.com for long-form work and a refreshed mobile app.
- Alexa+ pricing is competitive with ChatGPT and Google's Gemini Advanced, both at $19.99.
- Initial rumors suggested a price between $5 to $10 for a potential trial offer.

items.title: Amazon’s new Alexa+ brings AI-powered ‘Explore’ and ‘Stories’ features for kids
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Amazon has launched two new features for kids: **Explore with Alexa** and **Stories with Alexa**, as part of its new AI-powered Alexa+ assistant.
- The **Explore** feature allows kids to ask questions about various topics, with Alexa providing informative responses.
- In **Stories with Alexa**, kids can prompt Alexa to create stories, enhancing imaginative play.
- Amazon Kids+ subscription is priced at **$5.99/month** for Prime members and **$7.99/month** for non-Prime members, targeting children aged 3-12.

items.title: Amazon says that Alexa+ is ‘model agnostic’
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Amazon unveiled Alexa+, a new version that uses a "model agnostic" system.  
- Alexa+ utilizes Bedrock, Amazon's cloud platform for generative AI, and incorporates both Amazon Nova models and those from Anthropic.  
- It features a new system called "experts" for executing tasks and can interact with thousands of devices and services on day one.  
- Alexa+ can autonomously navigate websites, for instance, it can find and contact repair services.

items.title: Continue Aims to Help Developers Build Custom AI Coding Assistants
items.author: Ty Dunn, Nate Sesti
items.summary:
- Continue is a startup founded in June 2023 aimed at helping developers create customizable AI coding assistants.
- The company has received $3 million in seed funding and has about 23,000 GitHub stars and 11,000 Discord members.
- Their product supports integration with various data platforms and allows developers to create tailored autocomplete and chat experiences in coding environments.
- Continue's launch coincides with a surge in the AI coding assistant market, competing with tools like GitHub Copilot and Google’s Gemini Code Assist.
- The newly launched hub allows developers to create and share custom AI assistants and leverage blocks from verified partners.

items.title: Oliver Cameron discusses competing against incumbents at TechCrunch Sessions: AI
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Sessions: AI will take place on June 5, 2025, at UC Berkeley's Zellerbach Hall.
- Panel titled *How to Launch a Product Against Entrenched Incumbents* focuses on strategies for startups competing in the AI sector.
- Oliver Cameron, co-founder of Odyssey and former VP at Cruise, will be one of the panelists.
- The AI sector is experiencing significant investment, with $56 billion allocated by VCs in 2024, but competition is stiff due to incumbent companies' resources.
- Tickets for the event are available at Super Early Bird rates, offering savings up to $325.

items.title: Capim, a Brazilian BNPL startup for dental services, lands a $26.7M Series A
items.author: Marcelo Lutz, Roberto Biselli, Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Capim has raised $26.7 million in Series A funding for its BNPL dental service platform.
- Founded in July 2021, it supports dentists with software solutions and offers flexible payment plans of up to 36 installments.
- The startup aims to enhance its services with POS terminals and AI tools, expanding from 6,000 to over 10,000 dental clinics by year’s end.
- It has helped over 60,000 Brazilians access dental care and reported revenue tripling in 2024 despite still not being profitable.

items.title: Amazon Alexa+ can work with Prime Video and Fire TV to ‘jump to a scene’ in a movie
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Amazon introduces Alexa+ with new features for Prime Video and Fire TV.
- Users can ask Alexa+ to jump to specific scenes in movies by referencing characters or quotes.
- Alexa+ can identify songs from TV show credits even without knowing the title or artist.
- Additional upgrades include smart home device management and voice-controlled routine automation.

items.title: Alexa+ can work with Prime Video and Fire TV to ‘jump to a scene’ in a movie
Cellebrite suspends Serbia as customer after claims police used firm’s tech to plant spyware
Amazon unveils a new and improved Alexa, Alexa+
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Amazon announced upgraded Alexa experience, Alexa+, using generative AI technology.
- Alexa+ can answer personalized questions and notify users about relevant events, utilizing user account information.
- Enhanced capabilities include visual understanding and adapting responses based on environment and tone.
- Integrates with Amazon's smart home ecosystem, and can summarize security footage and interact with user files.
- Marketed as a productivity tool, with future updates to confirm reliability claims.

items.title: YouTube surpasses 1B monthly podcast viewers
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- YouTube announced it has surpassed 1 billion monthly active podcast viewers, competing with Spotify and Apple Podcasts.
- This milestone highlights the growing popularity of video-first formats in the podcast industry.
- Last year, over 400 million hours of podcast content were watched on living room TVs.
- Spotify has responded by investing more in video-first podcasting and paying video hosts based on performance.
- YouTube will implement changes to mid-roll ads from May 12 to improve viewer experience.

items.title: Microsoft finalizes its EU sovereign cloud project
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Microsoft has completed the EU Data Boundary project, allowing Europe-based customers to store and process cloud data in the EU.
- The project began in January 2023 and concluded in February 2025, enabling services like Microsoft 365 and Azure within EU and EFTA regions.
- This initiative supports compliance with European data protection laws such as GDPR.

items.title: Google makes it easier to delete personal info from Search results
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google updates its "Results about you" tool to simplify removal of personal information from Search results.
- Users can now submit removal requests directly from Search results via a new three-dot menu.
- The tool allows for monitoring and deleting personal details like phone numbers and email addresses.
- Users can also request a refresh if content about them has changed on the web but is not reflected in Search results.
- The feature is available in multiple countries including the U.S., U.K., Canada, and India.

items.title: TechCrunch Disrupt 2025: 3 days left to save up to $1,130 on passes
items.summary:
- Last chance to save up to $1,130 on passes for [TechCrunch Disrupt 2025](https://techcrunch.com/events/tc-disrupt-2025/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=disrupt2025&utm_content=post_seb3days_02262025&promo=post_seb3days_02262025&display=).
- Ticket sales end on February 28 at 11:59 p.m. PT, offering up to 30% off group tickets.
- Conference dates: October 27-29 at Moscone West, San Francisco, celebrating 20 years of TechCrunch Disrupt.
- Attendees can expect 250+ sessions and insights from 200+ experts, covering topics like AI, scaling businesses, and more.
- Featured event: [Startup Battlefield 200](https://techcrunch.com/events/tc-disrupt-2025/startup-battlefield/?promo=post_seb3days_02262025&utm_campaign=disrupt2025&utm_content=post_seb3days_02262025&utm_medium=post&utm_source=tc) where startups compete for equity-free prizes.
- Register now for the biggest ticket savings of 2025 before rates increase after February 28.

items.title: 5 days left — save over $300 to TechCrunch Sessions: AI
items.summary:
- Only 5 days left to register for [TechCrunch Sessions: AI](https://techcrunch.com/events/tc-sessions-ai/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=tcsessionsai&utm_content=post_seb5days_02262025&promo=post_seb5days_02262025&display=) with up to $325 in savings.
- Registration ends on March 3 at 11:59 p.m. PT for the event on June 5 at UC Berkeley's Zellerbach Hall.
- Join 1,200 leaders in AI for talks, breakout sessions, and demos featuring industry pioneers like Oliver Cameron, Kanu Gulati, Jill Chase, and Jae Lee.

items.title: Indonesia, Apple reach agreement to end iPhone 16 sales ban
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- Apple will resume sales of iPhone 16 in Indonesia after reaching an agreement.
- Ban lifted five months after Apple was blocked for failing to meet local component regulations.
- Apple will invest $1 billion in a factory in Indonesia to manufacture components for its devices.
- Indonesian Industry Minister stated Apple is obtaining a local content certificate to market devices.
- Apple CEO Tim Cook visited Indonesia and expressed intentions to explore manufacturing in the country.

items.title: Lock screen platform Glance launches AI-powered shopping experience, gets fresh backing from Google
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Glance has launched a generative AI-based shopping experience that personalizes outfit suggestions through user avatars.
- The company is collaborating with Google, utilizing their Gemini models and Vertex AI.
- Glance AI app is currently being tested in the U.S. and aims for wider rollout in the U.S. and India.
- Users upload selfies and choose personal attributes to create their AI-generated avatars.
- At launch, Glance has partnerships with 400 e-commerce sites and monetizes through affiliate links.
- The app also offers outfit suggestions on users' lock screens, with plans for future feature expansions.

items.title: Regie.ai injects sales enablement with AI, but keeps humans in the loop
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Regie.ai focuses on enhancing sales enablement through AI while retaining human involvement.
- Founded by Matt Millen and Srinath Sridhar in 2021, the company aims to amplify human sellers.
- Their tools include an AI-powered sales sequence builder and co-pilots for messaging personalization.
- Regie.ai analyzes buyer signals to decide if AI or a human rep should engage next.
- The sales enablement market was estimated at $5.23 billion in 2024, with intense competition present.
- Regie.ai recently closed a $30 million Series B funding round, increasing total funding to $50.8 million.

items.title: Anagram takes a gamified approach to employee cybersecurity training
items.author: Becca
items.summary:
- Anagram, formerly known as Cipher, is revolutionizing employee cybersecurity training with gamified methods.
- The platform offers hands-on security training, including interactive videos and personalized puzzles.
- Employees learn to spot phishing attempts by creating their own phishing emails.
- The company pivoted focus to non-security employees, seen as the weakest link in cybersecurity.
- Anagram recently raised a $10 million Series A funding to expand its sales team and improve its product.
- The startup claims to have reduced phishing failure rates from 20% to 6% and is developing an AI agent to flag potential cybersecurity issues in emails.

items.title: Bridgetown Research raises $19M to speed up due diligence with AI
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Bridgetown Research, an AI startup, raised $19M in Series A funding co-led by Accel and Lightspeed.
- The startup aims to reduce due diligence costs and time through AI agents for data collection and research.
- Founded by Harsh Sahai in December 2023, it has developed three types of AI agents for information gathering and analysis.
- The agents can provide initial due diligence analysis within 24 hours using inputs from hundreds of sources.
- Bridgetown partners with expert networks for insights, allowing for interviews without scheduling calls.
- Clients can use Bridgetown’s AI for self-service data gathering or work with consultants for lower-tier analysis.
- Technology includes a “steerability and auditability” approach to increase trust in AI-generated research.
- The company has two customers in the U.K. and about a dozen in the U.S., including private equity and venture capital firms.

items.title: Framework’s First Desktop PC Optimized for Gaming and AI Inference
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Framework has released its first desktop PC, designed for gaming and local AI inference.
- Features AMD's Strix Halo architecture (Ryzen AI Max processors) for high performance.
- Compact size at 4.5L, built on a mini-ITX mainboard, smaller than PS5 or Xbox Series X.
- Customizable front panel with 21 interchangeable tile colors and patterns.
- Includes iconic expansion cards for additional ports and functionalities.
- Two configurations available: Ryzen AI Max 385 with 8 cores and Ryzen AI Max+ 395 with 16 cores.
- RAM is soldered with options from 32GB to 128GB, but not upgradable.
- Base model starts at $1,099 and top-end version at $1,999; pre-orders available with shipments in early Q3 2025.

items.title: Nomagic picks up $44M for its AI-powered robotic arms
items.summary:
- Nomagic, a Polish startup, announces $44 million in funding for its AI-powered robotic arms aimed at logistics operations.
- The funding round is led by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), highlighting a push for industrial revitalization in Europe.
- Nomagic's robots focus on software advancements using computer vision and machine learning, achieving a 220% growth in annual recurring revenues last year, with projections for a further 200% growth this year.

items.title: Gozem nets $30M to expand vehicle financing, digital banking in Francophone Africa
items.author: Gregory Costamagna, Raphael Dana
items.summary:
- Gozem has raised $30 million in Series B funding to expand services across Francophone Africa.
- The funding comprises $15 million in equity and $15 million in debt, aimed at enhancing vehicle financing and entering new markets.
- Gozem offers a range of services including ride-hailing, commerce, vehicle financing, and digital banking to support professional drivers and their career growth opportunities.
- The company aims to finance more than 7,000 vehicles, utilizing a model that allows drivers to purchase vehicles through income deductions rather than upfront deposits.
- Gozem expects to grow significantly, aiming to triple or quadruple its growth in 2025 with this new capital.

items.title: Hackers publish sensitive patient data allegedly stolen from Australian IVF provider Genea
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- Hackers claim to have published sensitive data from IVF patients after a cyberattack on Genea.
- Genea CEO Tim Yeoh confirmed data was published externally following the breach.
- The Termite ransomware gang claimed responsibility and posted the data on their dark web site.
- The hackers breached Genea’s Citrix environment on January 31, extracting about 940 GB of data on February 14.
- Data possibly accessed includes patient management information, but no financial details were reportedly compromised.
- Genea is working to restore systems and communicate with affected patients.

items.title: Thousands of exposed GitHub repos, now private, can still be accessed through Copilot
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- Security researchers warn that briefly exposed data on GitHub may persist in generative AI tools like Microsoft Copilot.
- Over 20,000 previously public GitHub repositories are still accessible via Copilot, affecting more than 16,000 organizations including Amazon, Google, IBM, and Microsoft.
- Lasso, a cybersecurity firm, discovered that Copilot could retrieve sensitive information even from repositories set to private or deleted, prompting recommendations for affected organizations to revoke compromised data.

items.title: ElevenLabs now lets authors create and publish audiobooks on its own platform
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- ElevenLabs now allows authors to publish AI-generated audiobooks on its own Reader app.
- The announcement follows a partnership with Spotify for AI-narrated audiobooks.
- The publishing program, previously in trial, is now open to all authors.
- Authors are paid approximately $1.10 for engagement of 11 minutes or more; average listening time is 19 minutes.
- Initially, payouts are available for U.S. authors and English titles, with plans for 32 supported languages in the future.
- ElevenLabs aims to compete with Audible, offering better royalty rates and creating a marketplace for authors.
- The initiative is part of ElevenLabs CEO Mati Staniszewski’s vision to enhance consumer experiences with AI technology in audiobooks.

items.title: German startup wins accolade for its fusion reactor design
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Proxima Fusion, a German nuclear fusion startup, published plans for a working fusion power plant in a peer-reviewed journal.
- Its ‘Stellaris’ design aims to operate reliably and continuously without the instabilities of other fusion reactors like tokamaks.
- The company has raised $35 million from the EU and German government, targeting a fully operational reactor by 2031.
- Competitors include Commonwealth Fusion Systems, backed by Bill Gates’s venture fund.
- The findings were published in ‘Fusion Engineering and Design’ to support open-source science.

items.title: Claude: Everything you need to know about Anthropic’s AI
items.summary:
- Anthropic's Claude models can perform various tasks like captioning, writing, and solving challenges.  
- Latest models include Claude 3.5 Haiku, Claude 3.7 Sonnet, and Claude 3 Opus; with Sonnet being the flagship model optimized for reasoning.  
- Pricing: Claude 3.5 Haiku ($0.80/million input tokens), Claude 3.7 Sonnet ($3/million input tokens), Claude 3 Opus ($15/million input tokens).  
- Available through Anthropic's API and platforms like Amazon Bedrock and Google Cloud.  
- Users can choose reasoning modes with Claude 3.7 Sonnet, enhancing its ability to analyze prompts.  
- Risks of AI models include potential inaccuracies, hallucinations, and copyright concerns from training data.

items.title: How much does ChatGPT cost? Everything you need to know about OpenAI’s pricing plans
items.summary:
- OpenAI’s ChatGPT offers a variety of pricing plans, including free and paid options for individuals, businesses, and educational institutions.
- The free version allows access to the GPT-4o mini model with limited features; users can save chat preferences and analyze uploaded data.
- ChatGPT Plus costs $20/month, allows 80 messages to GPT-4o every three hours, and includes more advanced features like multimodal capabilities.
- ChatGPT Pro, priced at $200/month, provides unlimited access to models and the latest features along with priority support.
- ChatGPT Team is available for $30/user/month, focusing on collaboration for small businesses, while ChatGPT Enterprise targets larger organizations with pricing based on user volume.
- OpenAI for Nonprofits offers discounted plans for eligible organizations, including ChatGPT Team and ChatGPT Enterprise at reduced rates.
- The article was updated on February 25, 2025, to reflect new pricing and features.

items.title: Y Combinator deletes posts after a startup’s demo goes viral
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- A demo from Optifye.ai, part of Y Combinator’s current cohort, led to criticism and YC removing the video from their social media.
- The demo showcased AI-powered software designed to monitor factory workers’ productivity in real-time, featuring a conversation between co-founders about a low-performing worker.
- The clip faced backlash on social media for promoting exploitative labor practices; however, some supported the approach, citing existing practices in certain industries.

items.title: Anthropic’s latest flagship AI might not have been incredibly costly to train
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Anthropic’s Claude 3.7 Sonnet cost "a few tens of millions of dollars" to train, requiring less than 10^26 FLOPs of computing power.
- The cost reflects how training state-of-the-art models is becoming relatively cheaper compared to previous models like GPT-4, which cost over $100 million.
- CEO Dario Amodei anticipates future models will be much larger and may cost billions, indicating rising costs for AI model development and deployment.

items.title: Perplexity launches $50M seed and pre-seed VC fund
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Perplexity is raising a $50 million seed and pre-seed investment fund.
- The majority of capital is from limited partners, with some from Perplexity's previous growth funds.
- Perplexity raised $500 million at a $9 billion valuation in December 2024.
- The fund is managed by Kelly Graziadei and Joanna Lee Shevelenko, co-founders of F7 Ventures.
- F7 Ventures has invested in startups, including women's health company Midi.
- It is unclear if Graziadei and Shevelenko will continue with F7 Ventures while managing the new fund.
- OpenAI also has an investment fund but claims it does not use its own capital for investments.

items.title: The people in Elon Musk’s DOGE universe
items.summary:
- Elon Musk has created a network of companies that supports engineers and tech talent, now intersecting with the U.S. federal government.
- TechCrunch identified individuals working with Musk related to the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) and their connections.
- The DOGE initiative aims at improving government efficiency and accountability, linked to President Trump’s commitment.
- Musk serves as an unpaid “Special Government Employee” and senior advisor to the president under DOGE, set to expire in July 2026.
- Current individuals involved include long-time confidants and new hires from Musk’s previous ventures like SpaceX and Twitter.

items.title: DOGE has an official ‘acting’ administrator, and it’s not Elon Musk, White House confirms
items.author: Amy Gleason
items.summary:
- Amy Gleason has been appointed as the acting administrator of DOGE, confirmed by the White House.
- This is the first acknowledgment of oversight for DOGE, previously leaving roles ambiguous regarding Elon Musk.
- DOGE was established through an executive order signed by President Trump, renaming the U.S. Digital Service.
- Gleason reports to the White House chief of staff, Susie Wiles.
- Musk remains deeply involved with DOGE despite not being its official head.

items.title: Anthropic’s Claude AI is playing Pokémon on Twitch — slowly
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Anthropic launched [Claude Plays Pokémon](https://www.twitch.tv/claudeplayspokemon) on Twitch, featuring Claude 3.7 Sonnet playing Pokémon Red.
- The AI model has successfully won three gym leader badges but still faces challenges, like getting stuck at a rock wall.
- The Twitch stream showcases Claude's thought process alongside gameplay, reminiscing about the earlier Twitch experiment, [Twitch Plays Pokémon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitch_Plays_Pok%C3%A9mon).

items.title: Lucid Motors CEO Peter Rawlinson steps down
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Lucid Motors announces Peter Rawlinson is stepping down as CEO and CTO, with Marc Winterhoff appointed as interim CEO.
- Rawlinson will serve as a strategic technical advisor to Turqi Alnowaiser, chairman of the board.
- The leadership change follows the launch of the Gravity SUV, as the company aims to recover from poor sales of its previous model, the Air sedan.
- Lucid Motors delivered 10,241 EVs in 2024, generating $808 million in revenue but still incurred a loss of $2.7 billion.

items.title: Apptronik’s humanoid robots take the first steps toward building themselves
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Apptronik announces a new pilot partnership with Jabil to scale humanoid robot production.
- The deal follows a $350 million Series A funding round and an ongoing pilot with Mercedes-Benz.
- Jabil will manufacture the Apollo robot once it is commercially viable, with plans to have humanoids potentially build themselves.
- Apollo robots will perform simple tasks at Jabil’s factory to validate their capabilities, targeting 2026 for commercial production.

items.title: OpenAI rolls out deep research to paying ChatGPT users
items.summary:
- OpenAI announced on February 25, 2025, the rollout of its deep research feature to all paying ChatGPT users, including ChatGPT Plus, Team, Enterprise, and Edu subscribers.
- Each user will get 10 deep research queries per month; ChatGPT Pro users will receive 120 queries, up from 100 at launch.
- OpenAI is competing with Google and Perplexity in the deep research market, which aims to deliver value to AI subscription users. Google recently expanded its deep research agent to all Gemini Advanced users.

items.title: Framous is a new Mac app for adding device frames to screenshots
items.author: Charlie Chapman, Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Framous, a new Mac app, allows users to add device frames to screenshots for a more professional appearance.
- It is particularly useful for app developers, graphic designers, and journalists.
- Created by Dark Noise developer Charlie Chapman, Framous simplifies the process of adding frames, requiring just drag-and-drop or copy-paste actions.
- Features include automatic device frame detection, landscape mode for iPhones, and customization options like frame color and edge-to-edge mode.
- Future updates include more customization options, video support, and an iOS app planned for development.
- Available for free in the Mac App Store with a one-time fee of $19.99 to unlock all 2025 frames or a $9.99 yearly subscription.

items.title: Apple shareholders vote down anti-DEI proposal
items.summary:
- Apple shareholders rejected an anti-DEI proposal at the investor meeting on Tuesday.
- The proposal was made by the conservative group National Center for Public Policy Research (NPPR) and sought to end DEI activities.
- This proposal gained national attention amidst other tech companies trimming or eliminating DEI programs due to social and legal pressures.
- CEO Tim Cook indicated that changes might be necessary as the legal landscape evolves, according to reports.
keywords: National Center for Public Policy Research
